meanings.definition: To cast (an actor) in an unsuitable role.
meanings.sent1: The director miscast the lead actor as a villain, even though he was better suited for a hero role.
meanings.sent2: The producer realized they had miscast the actress as a scientist when she struggled with the technical jargon.
meanings.sent3: It was quite a sight to see the comedy actor miscast as a serious detective in the movie.
meanings.sent4: The teacher miscast the student as the class clown, not realizing his talent for dramatic monologues.
meanings.sent5: The director's decision to miscast the lead role left the audience confused and disappointed.

meanings.definition: To assign an unsuitable role to (an actor).
meanings.sent1: The casting director miscast the young actress as an elderly grandmother, which didn't fit her age at all.
meanings.sent2: The director didn't want to miscast the actor, so he carefully considered each role before making a decision.
meanings.sent3: It was a hilarious mistake when the director accidentally miscast the dog as the main character in the play.
meanings.sent4: The producer's attempt to miscast the lead actor as a background extra backfired when he stole the spotlight.
meanings.sent5: The decision to miscast the lead role led to a series of unfortunate events during the filming process.

meanings.definition: To make a mistake in casting.
meanings.sent1: The director didn't mean to miscast the actor, but the mix-up in auditions led to the error.
meanings.sent2: The casting agent apologized for the miscast and promised to find a more suitable role for the actor.
meanings.sent3: It was a comedy of errors when the director accidentally miscast the entire ensemble in the Shakespearean play.
meanings.sent4: The miscast in the school play turned out to be a blessing in disguise, as the actor excelled in the unexpected role.
meanings.sent5: The audience couldn't help but notice the miscast in the play, leading to whispers and confusion in the theater.
